article_text:
The State And Federal Evolution Of LGBT Workplace Rights

Law360, New York (January 21, 2016, 9:38 PM ET) -- Jim S. McNeill



Peter Stockburger 2015 was a watershed year for the politics of sex. The Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage in June, and Time magazine called 2015 America’s “transgender tipping point.” From Caitlyn Jenner to movies and television, lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender issues occupied the foreground of our cultural and political landscape.



2015 was also a year of legal change. A number of states passed legislation expressly banning discrimination in the workplace against persons on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity. Federal...

article_metadata.description: 2015 saw a wide range of developments for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender issues. While federal law has not changed, a number of states passed legislation banning discrimination in the workplace against persons on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, and recent trends indicate the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will continue to aggressively enforce Title VII broadly in 2016, say attorneys at Dentons LLP.
